claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers type I interferon signaling.

evidence.quote: | Type I interferon response score (normalized units) | 3.1 | 1.0 | Marked induction after mRNA vaccination in tumors |
1. Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling.

claims.caveat: Results derived from specific models requiring careful translation to broad clinical settings.

claims.claim: mRNA vaccination broadens tumor antigen display.

evidence.quote: | Fraction of tumor proteins represented in immunopeptidome | 62.3% | 37.3% | Broader antigen display after intratumoral mRNA vaccination |
3. A broader peptide repertoire appears on MHC-I, improving tumor visibility to T cells.

claims.caveat: Effects are based on preclinical metrics and may vary across distinct tumor types.

claims.claim: Prior mRNA vaccination is associated with improved survival in patients receiving ICI.

evidence.quote: | Retrospective human survival comparison p-value | p=0.01 | N/A | Vaccinated subgroup had improved survival under ICI treatment |
- The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely.

claims.caveat: Retrospective observational design and varied vaccination timing limit definitive causal interpretation.

claims.claim: Combination therapy increases immune infiltration into tumors.

evidence.quote: | Intratumoral CD8+ T-cell density fold-change | 1.8x | 1.0x | Increased immune infiltration with combination therapy |
5. Combined intervention improves tumor control in mice and aligns with better outcomes in the retrospective human cohort.

claims.caveat: Increased infiltration measured in mouse models may not uniformly guarantee clinical response in all human tumors.
